info.title: Tracker API
info.description:
# Beta Release

The current api release is beta. Though we do not expect any breaking changes as a beta this is potentially subject to change. Please integrate with this in mind.

# Intended Audience

This document is intended for technically trained developers. Please ensure you share this with developers who intend to implement the API. Support will not be provided for non technically trained users.

# Introduction
[comment]: <> (x-product-description-placeholder)
The Tracker API is built on HTTP and is RESTful.
It has predictable resource URLs and returns HTTP response codes to indicate errors.

It returns JSON in the HTTP body.
Use the HTTP/REST library in your favorite programming language when using this API,
or generate a client SDK using your preferred development IDE.

Many [Tracker](https://my.tracker-rms.com) actions are supported by APIs which are documented and available for use, so that you may automate any necessary workflows or processes.
This API reference documentation contains the most commonly integrated resources.

# Authentication

**All calls to this API require an authorised JWT token**, which is obtained by exchanging a valid OAuth2 token for a JWT token using the **/api/auth/exchangetoken** endpoint.

The token is acquired with the [OAuth2](https://oauth.net/2/) authentication flow using our [OAuth2 API](/swagger/index.html?urls.primaryName=OAuth2+API).

Authentication steps

1. Acquire a token using the OAuth2 flow with the **/oauth2/authorize** and **/oauth2/token** endpoints\
   See the [OAuth2 API](/swagger/index.html?urls.primaryName=OAuth2+API) documentation for details on these endpoints and note in particular that they are published on a separate domain to this API
2. Exchange your token for a JWT token using the **/api/auth/exchangetoken** endpoint
3. Send your JWT token in the **Authorization** header with all subsequent calls to the API

**Important: JWT tokens expire, so you should always check for an authentication failure (401) response and obtain a new JWT token by calling the /api/auth/exchangetoken endpoint, if necessary.**

# Errors

Tracker follows the error response format proposed in [RFC 9457](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc9457),
which is also known as Problem Details for HTTP APIs.

As with any API responses, your client must be prepared to gracefully handle additional members of the response.

# Rate Limits

Tracker implements rate limiting on the API. Presently around 100 requests per minute.

If the rate limit is exceeded, the API returns a '429 Too Many Requests' response. 

# Response Codes

This API follows REST specification. For convenience below is a table of returned response codes:

| **Code** | **Meaning**                                                                 |
|----------|------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| 200 OK   | The request was successful.                                                  |
| 201 Created | A new resource has been successfully created.                            |
| 202 Accepted | The request has been accepted for processing, but the processing is not complete. |
| 204 No Content | The request was successful, but there is no content to return.        |
| 400 Bad Request | The request was malformed or invalid. Check the request parameters or body. |
| 401 Unauthorized | Authentication is required or has failed. Verify your JWT token.    |
| 403 Forbidden | The client does not have permission to access the requested resource.   |
| 404 Not Found | The requested resource could not be found.                             |
| 405 Method Not Allowed | The HTTP method is not supported for the requested resource.  |
| 409 Conflict | The request could not be completed due to a conflict with the current state of the resource. |
| 415 Unsupported Media Type | The request entity has a media type that the server does not support. |
| 422 Unprocessable Entity | The server understands the content type and syntax, but the content is semantically invalid. |
| 429 Too Many Requests | The client has sent too many requests in a given amount of time (rate limiting). |
| 500 Internal Server Error | A generic error occurred on the server.                    |
| 502 Bad Gateway | The server received an invalid response from an upstream server.     |
| 503 Service Unavailable | The server is currently unavailable, usually due to maintenance or overload. |

These status codes are returned in the HTTP response status line, and error responses may include a body formatted according to [RFC 9457 (Problem Details)](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc9457) for additional context.

post.summary: Creates a new activity
Searches for activities using the supplied parameters
post.description:
Sample request:

     POST /
     {
       	"subject": "John Doe",
	        "maxResults": 50,
	        "pageNumber": 1,
	        "sortBy": "name",
	        "sortDirection": "desc",
	        "updatedBefore": null,
	        "updatedAfter": null,
	        "onlyMyRecords": false,
	        "includeCustomFields": false
     }

get.summary: Gets an existing activity

post.summary: Exchanges a Tracker OAuth2 token for an API JWT token

endDateTime.description: Date when the activity is due to finish

tags.name: Activity
tags.description: Activities log events that have taken place (like phone calls, email sends, interviews and tasks).

tags.name: Auth
tags.description:
A JWT token is required for all API calls. Authenticate via OAuth2 API
then exchange the token for a JWT.

JWT tokens must be passed to all API calls in the 'Authorization' header.

tags.name: Client
tags.description: Clients represent other companies and businesses with which you have a relationship.

tags.name: Contact
tags.description: Contacts represent people with which you have a relationship.

tags.name: Invoice
tags.description: Invoice records represent invoices raised in your database.

tags.name: MetaData
tags.description: Obtain all the core access rights, naming conventions, statues, types, sources and teams for a given user.

tags.name: Opportunity
tags.description: Opportunities represent business opportunities such as jobs.

tags.name: OpportunityResource
tags.description: OpportunityResources represent placements - resources that are shortlisted or placed on opportunities.

tags.name: PartnerRecord
tags.description: PartnerRecords represent mappings between records in external systems and internal records

tags.name: ProjectActivity
tags.description: Project Activity represent tasks linked to a project. On which resources are assigned

tags.name: ProjectActivityResource
tags.description: Project Activity represent tasks linked to a project. On which resources are assigned

tags.name: Project
tags.description: Projects represent projects on which your resources are working.

tags.name: Resource
tags.description: Resources represent people (like candidates and employees) in your database.

tags.name: TimesheetEntries
tags.description: Timesheet entries records represent timesheets records raised in your database.

tags.name: Webhook
tags.description: Webhooks provide real time updates when activities and records are created, updated and deleted.
